posts.name: Evan Kaufman
posts.cooked:
A feature that evidently was removed when encrypted backups were added/finished was creating a plain text backup of conversations.

This is a feature I personally made use of to regularly preserve correspondence with certain contacts. I would very much like a way to get my data out of Signal that doesn’t involve an unofficial third party tool. I get that it shouldn’t be the preferred method for most people, but it should still be an option.

link_counts.title: GitHub - xeals/signal-back: Decrypt Signal encrypted backups outside the app
Export to stock SMS database. · Issue #8 · signalapp/Signal-Android · GitHub

Raw text/html chat export via iOS share sheet
Mark Zuckerberg: "A Privacy-Focused Vision for Social Networking"
Raw text/html chat export via iOS share sheet

posts.cooked:
I think the Signal Foundation is firmly against that, as one of their ways of keeping Signal the most private messenger.
I do tend to agree with them. A plain text backup might add some convenience, but at the end of the day, it would mean that any one of my contacts could export our supposedly private, encrypted and secret conversation as plain text and store it in their insecure computer/cloud/USB stick. Not something a privacy-promoting messenger would like to promote.
I completely agree and dont want to have a plain text backup.

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
DonDino:

but at the end of the day, it would mean that any one of my contacts could export our supposedly private, encrypted and secret conversation as plain text and store it in their insecure computer/cloud/USB stick

They can do that now also by exporting it from the encrypted backup (there are tools for that), or by making a screenshot, or even by writing the message down by hand.

Well it will probably always be possible to create a tool to decrypt the file seeing as the encrypting code is open source. But like you say, there are tools for that, which make it a more specialised task for those who really need to do it and want to go through the time and effort.
Screenshots can be disabled, although then of course someone could use a 2nd phone to take a photo of the conversation on the 1st phone - that would be someone who really wants/needs to do that for a very specific purpose, again not your average user.
What Signal wants to protect against (I would argue) is mainly the average user who will carelessly back up in plain text or enable an unencrypted backup to GDrive (as in WhatsApp, for example), and still think that their messaging is secret and secure.
If there is someone hellbent on exposing your conversation with them, they can figure out a way and no amount of protection can stop it. But Signal can go a long way towards protecting us against the obvious and easy ways of having a less secure environment and higher chances of messages being exposed.

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
DonDino:

Screenshots can be disabled

But not on the device of someone else.

johanw666:

They can do that now also by exporting it from the encrypted backup (there are tools for that), or by making a screenshot, or even by writing the message down by hand.

A “freak” will always find ways to do it. You can also build your own signal version and all incoming chats will automatically be send as .txt to your gmail address.
But the “normal” user, who can just download an app and then use it, will not export anything as text, if the app does not offer that option. And 98% are normal users.

You will never be able to prevent people from doing things, which are not secure, from “abusing” a security app. You can just reduce the percentage, which is able to do so.
If an app is not open source, sure, someone can get the code by reserve engineering and change it, but then only 0,001% of all users are capable of doing this.
Plain text backups are a big no no and should not be re-implemented into Signal at all. It would completely undermine Signal’s position as a secure comm app.

posts.name: Evan Kaufman
posts.cooked: Well, that’s disappointing. Thanks for the response.

posts.name: Joshua Lund
posts.cooked:
There are still options available for users with specialized archival needs. I responded to this in a little more detail here:

Let's talk about backups General Discussion
Before: Backups were incomplete. Backups were plaintext. Users with specialized archival needs could export a tiny subset of message details in a single format that was completely missing images and attachments. Today: Backups are complete. Backups are encrypted. Users with specialized archival needs can use one of several open source utilities (like signal-back) to export all message details in multiple formats that include images, videos, files, and any other attachments. Signal Android …

Thank you jlund for explaining it very well. I am a user that neets specialized achival. But signal-back does not work anymore and I needed to export my chats for searching in plain text at my secured pc. What can I do?

My program should still be able to decrypt the backups. I have just never bothered to write an XML exporter (mainly because I have never found any documentation on what a ‘compliant’ XML should look like). Still, you could just dump the entire decrypted database to a folder and open the sqlite database to view your messages (or export them from the sqlite). Code is here if you want to give it a try: GitHub - bepaald/signalbackup-tools: Tool to work with Signal Backup files.

If anyone has any pointers to (proper) documentation for the xml format for messages, I could probably get my program to export to xml in a few days.

link_counts.title: GitHub - bepaald/signalbackup-tools: Tool to work with Signal Backup files.

posts.name: Bill
posts.cooked:
Well it was a shock to find that I can no longer export messages!

I must be able to print messages with date/timestamps for legal proceedings, and now I can not do that! I do not run Windows so can not use signal-back.

What am I supposed to do now that the subject messages are encased in Signal?

See my previous post (right above yours). If you cannot use the decrypted sqlite database directly, tell me what format you need from your output. If it’s fairly simple, for example, a plain text file containing ‘conversation_partner,date_sent,date_received,message_body’, I can probably have that working by tomorrow. If you need something more complicated (properly formatted xml, or a pdf or something), it will probably take a bit longer. So, if you want, see if you can get my program running, then just let me know what you need and I’ll see what I can do.

I miss this feature too, and switched to using a fork of Signal that kept it (along with the additional conversation colours they removed). It doesn’t make sense that Signal will not support such a feature and maintain this vendor lock in. Their excuse is privacy, however anyone can install one of the Signal forks which support plaintext backup, or they can use unofficial third party tools that they themselves tell you about when you bring this issue up. So they are basically telling you to use third party solutions to circumvent the reason they won’t do it themselves. Why would they not just offer official support at that point so that we don’t have to use third party tools? If people are going to do it anyways, you may as well adopt the feature as your own.
Where can someone find a signal fork that still supports unencrypted backups?

Hey, thanks a lot. For me a simple text export would be fine enough, but i cannot install your program. I’ve never compiled a programm before, just used pre-compiled .deb-programs. I tried to understand your description. My output is “g++: error: unrecognized command line option ‘-std=c++2a’; did you mean ‘-std=c++03’” and I use kubuntu. Can you help me?

Actually if I would ever manage to find out, that someone I’m involved in a chat with, is using any kind of modified Signal client (besides the official three versions of App Store, Google Play or the official apk), I would at once stop writing them at all.
For me Signal is mainly about the privacy of the content I write and receive, and any kind of export would destroy that.
Also disappearing messages make only sense, as long as my interlocutor is using official versions of Signal.

It would be nice if it would be possible to integrate a warning when starting a chat, that the other side is not using any official version. Doubt that it’s possible easily

@Konsumopfer I’ve heard this same problem many times (a lot of people use Ubuntu for some reason ). As noted in the README file, recent versions of some software is required for compiling the program. Unfortunately, Ubuntu chooses to supply its users with old (sometimes even ancient) versions of software. The problem you are seeing is because you have an old compiler installed, the program needs at least gcc-c++ version 9 to compile. I think you could get a newer compiler in Ubuntu, however Ubuntu’s version of cryptopp is even older and as far as I know now newer version is available.

People have successfully built the program under Arch, Fedora and Debian, so any of those should work if you want to try (I run Arch, but recommend Fedora for novice users, try the KDE Live Spin, no need to install).

I have just pushed an update to export to CSV file, just as signal-back used to do. If you manage to build the program running ./signalbackup-tools [file.backup] [passphrase] --exportcsv [output] should give you two cvs files ([output]_sms.csv and [output]_mms.csv) containing a plain text dump of the data in the sms and mms tables of the database.

@LaraM

LaraM:

For me Signal is mainly about the privacy of the content I write and receive, and any kind of export would destroy that.

You do realize the official version already has ‘any kind of export’ (at least on Android)? An encrypted one, but it’s still an export. Besides there are many third party tools to decrypt the exported backups (and I think that’s a good thing!).

Yes of course I know that, but an encrypted backup and a plain text export are - at least from my point of view - two completely different things.
A plaintext export could be used, and would be used by a significant number of people, to export the chat and send it to your email account or save it on Dropbox.
Actually everyone has to decide, whether he is interested in using a privacy focused tool or not. People who are just interested in keeping their chats forever and copy plain text to every insecure place they find - they should simply not use Signal. Because if they still do so, they are a threat for the complete security and/or privacy focused Signal community.

bepaald:

You do realize the official version already has ‘any kind of export’ (at least on Android)? An encrypted one
